hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the graph. Each node can be connected to other nodes via edges, forming connected components. Think about how you can identify these connected components.
Consider using Depth First Search (DFS) or Breadth First Search (BFS) to explore the graph. This will help you traverse and find all nodes that are reachable from a given starting node.
As you explore the graph, keep track of the size of each connected component. You can maintain a list or an array to store the sizes of these components.
Remember that pairs of nodes are unreachable if they belong to different connected components. Once you have the sizes of all components, you can calculate the number of unreachable pairs.

To calculate the number of unreachable pairs, use the formula: For each component of size 's', the number of unreachable pairs with nodes from this component and all other components is 's * (n - s)'.
Iterate through the list of component sizes and apply the formula to accumulate the total number of unreachable pairs. Be careful to avoid double counting.
Consider edge cases, such as when there are no edges at all. In this case, every node is its own component, and you can directly calculate the unreachable pairs.
Think about the constraints given in the problem. The number of nodes can be quite large (up to 100,000), so ensure your approach is efficient, ideally O(n + e), where e is the number of edges.
When implementing your solution, ensure that you handle the input correctly. The edges array should not contain duplicates, and nodes are indexed from 0 to n-1.
Finally, once you have the total count of unreachable pairs, return that value. Make sure your return statement matches the expected output format of the problem.

questionNotes: Constraints: 1 <= n <= 100,000; 0 <= edges.length <= 200,000; edges[i].length == 2; 0 <= a_i, b_i < n; a_i != b_i.
There are no repeated edges in the input.
Output should be the total count of unreachable pairs of nodes.
